name: Gyárfás–Sumner conjecture
rephrased: For any given tree and complete graph, there exists a fixed number of colors such that any graph without those specific tree or complete graph as an induced subgraph can be properly colored with that constant number of colors.
implication_form: If a graph does not contain a given tree or complete graph as an induced subgraph, then it can be properly colored using at most a constant number of colors.
explained: The Gyárfás–Sumner conjecture states that for any given tree T and complete graph K, there exists a constant c(T,K) such that every graph that does not contain T or K as an induced subgraph has a chromatic number at most c(T,K). In other words, if a graph avoids having T or K as an induced subgraph, then its chromatic number is bounded by some constant that depends only on T and K, not on the size of the graph.
subjects: Computer science (specifically algorithms and graph algorithms)
